document_data.name: Pentekonter
document_data.mainbody: '''Pentekonters''' were a type [[galley]]<ref group="note" name="disclaimer">Within the supplement ''Of Ships and the Sea'' (1997), penekonters are described as being a type of bireme, but historically they were monoremes (a ship with a single row of oars) and lacked any such hollowed outriggers. This misinformation is carried over in the description of a pentekonter in the novel ''Rising Tide'' (1999). that could be found in the Realms.{{Cite digital book/Rising Tide|?|4}}
document_data.Description:
On average, from bow to stern these ships measured {{SI|60|ft|long=yes}} in length, had a beam (width) of {{SI|15|ft|long=yes}}, and required a depth of at least {{SI|2|ft|long=yes}} in order to float. They had large, square sails and were always outfitted with a sharply pointed ram, just below the surface of the water. Their prows were rounded, making them look sluggish, but they were deceptively fast ships.

These ships had two banks of [[oar]]s,<ref group="note" name="disclaimer" /> which enabled greater speeds to be achieved when necessary. The second bank of oars was stationed in hollowed outriggers attached to the hull, a level below the raised deck, which helped pentekonters to maintain stability.<ref group="note" name="disclaimer" /> They held enough space to carry up to {{SI|10|ton|k|long=yes}} of cargo, but lacked any specialized quarters for passengers.

Each pentekonter could be manned by a crew of sixty individuals, all rowers, but could easily fit an extra fifty [[warrior]] passengers in place of cargo. The bare minimum of rowers necessary to sail a pentekonter was twenty, with the other forty acting as a skeleton crew.
document_data.History: On [[Ches 30]], in the {{YearlinkName|1369}}, as part of the [[Twelfth Ser√¥s War]], [[Iakhovas]] sneaked a horde of his [[sahuagin]] and [[wererat]]s into [[Waterdeep Harbor]] by means of a modified penekonter to enact a surprise raid. The ship had a hole made in its hull, allowing its sahuagin crew to submerge themselves in the water every four hours. Whenever this occurred someone else had to take the rower's place, as they had to be submerged for an equal amount of time before they returned to full strength. To compensate for this hole in the hull, the hollowed outriggers were modified. This consequently caused the ship to be submerged within the water at a lower depth than a standard pentekonter.
